pageContext.description:
A copper-alloy awl, probably dating from the Late Bronze Age



The widest part of the awl is approximately one third of the way along its length; either side of this point, the piece tapers. The longer portion is of rectangular cross section, displays evidence of filing on its surfaces and tapers to a wedge-shaped terminal. The remaining third also has a broadly rectangular cross section, but in this portion the corners have been deliberately removed, probably by filing. The patinated surfaces are almost black in some areas, perhaps suggesting that a coating was applied in antiquity.



Length: 54.1 mm; maximum width: 4.7 mm. Weight: 5.01 g.
